A New Perspective on Stochastic Local Search and the Lov√°sz Local Lemma

Dimitris Achlioptas
University of California Santa Cruz
optas@cs.ucsc.edu
Research supported by NSF grant CCF-1514434. ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Fotis Iliopoulos
University of California Berkeley
fotis.iliopoulos@berkeley.edu
Research supported by NSF grant CCF-1514434 and the Onassis Foundation. ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Alistair Sinclair
University of California Berkeley
sinclair@berkeley.edu Research supported by NSF grant CCF-1514434.

Abstract

We present a new perspective on the analysis of stochastic local search algorithms, via linear algebra, and use it to establish a new criterion for their convergence. Our criterion captures and unifies the analysis of all currently known LLL-inspired local search algorithms, including all current applications of the entropy compression method. It can be seen as a generalization of the Lov√°sz Local Lemma that quantifies the interaction strength of bad events, so that weak interactions form correspondingly small obstacles to algorithmic convergence. As a demonstration of its power, we use our criterion to analyze a complex local search algorithm for the classical problem of coloring graphs with sparse neighborhoods. We prove that any improvement over our algorithm would require a major (and unexpected) breakthrough in random graph theory, suggesting that our criterion reaches the edge of tractability for this problem. Finally, we consider questions such as the number of possible distinct final states and the probability that certain portions of the state space are visited by a local search algorithm. Such information is currently available for the Moser-Tardos algorithm and for algorithms satisfying a combinatorial notion of commutativity introduced of Kolmogorov. Our framework provides a very natural and more general notion of commutativity (essentially matrix commutativity) which allows the recovery of all such results with much simpler proofs.

1 Introduction

Stochastic local search algorithms.

Numerous problems in computer science and combinatorics can be formulated as finding an object that lacks certain bad properties, or ‚Äúflaws‚Äù. For example, constraint satisfaction problems like boolean satisfiability or graph coloring can be seen as searching for an object (a truth assignment or coloring) that is flawless in the sense that it does not violate any constraint. A large class of algorithms for finding such objects that are very popular in practice are known as ‚Äústochastic local search‚Äù algorithms; these algorithms start with a flawed object and attempt to gradually improve it via local, randomized changes that focus at each step on a specific flaw and try to eradicate it. Given their simplicity and success in practice, it is natural to ask whether there are conditions under which stochastic local search algorithms provably work efficiently, and to use them to show that interesting families of instances of hard problems are in fact tractable.

Towards that end, Moser [40], later joined by Tardos [41], discovered in groundbreaking work that a simple local search algorithm can be used to make constructive the majority of applications of the Lov√°sz Local Lemma (LLL) [20]. The LLL is a powerful and widely applied tool for proving the existence of flawless objects, with far-reaching consequences in computer science and combinatorics. Roughly it states that, given a collection of a bad events (flaws) in a probability space, if most events are mutually independent and each of them individually is not too likely, then the probability of avoiding all of them is strictly positive; hence a flawless object exists. As an example, for k-SAT the LLL implies that if each clause shares variables with at most 2k/e other clauses, then the formula is satisfiable. The Moser-Tardos algorithm in this case amounts to starting at a uniformly random truth assignment and, at each step, choosing a violated clause and resampling all of its variables uniformly at random.

Following the work of Moser and Tardos, a large amount of effort (see, e.g., [35, 44, 30, 3, 23, 32, 2, 37]) has been devoted to extending their analysis to capture constructively all known variants and applications of the LLL. Moreover, and perhaps more surprisingly, a plethora of papers (see, e.g., [26, 21, 19, 24, 25, 43, 4, 38]) use similar techniques to analyze local search algorithms for various combinatorial problems without an explicit reference to a known form of the LLL.

To illustrate the current state of the art, we require some notation. Let Œ© be a (large) discrete space and Œº a probability measure on Œ©. (In the classical LLL Œº is specified in advance; in more general settings it may be defined by the algorithm designer.) We are given a set {f1,‚Ä¶,fm} of ‚Äúbad‚Äù events (or ‚Äúflaws‚Äù) on Œ©, and our task is to give conditions for the existence of, and if possible to find, a ‚Äúflawless‚Äù object, i.e., an object in Œ©‚àñŒ©‚àó, where Œ©‚àó=‚ãÉifi. We consider a class of local search algorithms that move between states œÉ‚ààŒ© by choosing a flaw that is present in the current state œÉ, i.e., œÉ‚ààfi, and attempting to fix it (i.e., leave fi) by moving to a nearby state according to some local randomized rule. We refer to an effort to fix a flaw, successful or not, as addressing the flaw. The algorithm halts as soon as it finds a flawless state.

In this setting, the most general currently available (existential and algorithmic) condition takes the following form [2, 37]. Let Œì(i) be the neighborhood of flaw fi in the directed ‚Äúcausality‚Äù graph, i.e., the set of flaws fj such that addressing flaw fi may introduce fj. (The causality graph is a generalization of the ‚Äúdependency graph‚Äù in the classical LLL.) Let Œ≥i‚â•Œº(fi) measure the extent to which the search algorithm faithfully reproduces the underlying probability measure Œº when addressing flaw fi; see later for a precise definition of Œ≥i.

Algorithmic LLL:  If there exist positive real numbers {œài}mi=1 such that for all i‚àà[m],

Œ≥iœài‚àëS‚äÜŒì(i)‚àèj‚ààSœàj<1, (1)

then a flawless object exists. Moreover, a stochastic local search algorithm of the above type finds a flawless object efficiently whp.

(To recover the classical LLL, replace the sum over Œì(i) by a sum over the neighborhood of fi in the dependency graph, and Œ≥i by Œº(fi). When the causality graph is undirected, (1) can be sharpened to the so-called ‚Äúcluster expansion‚Äù criterion [14] and to Shearer‚Äôs criterion [46].)

In this paper we introduce a new framework for the analysis of local search algorithms, based on linear algebra. As we shall see presently, our framework will result in a sharpening of the above algorithmic LLL condition that also provides a more powerful tool for the design and analysis of local search algorithms.

A new perspective via linear algebra.

To describe this framework, imagine a particle trying to escape Œ©‚àó by following a Markov chain1 on Œ© with transition matrix P. Our task is to develop conditions under which the particle eventually escapes, thus establishing in particular that Œ©‚àó‚â†Œ©. Letting A be the |Œ©‚àó|√ó|Œ©‚àó| submatrix of P that corresponds to transitions from Œ©‚àó to Œ©‚àó, and B the submatrix that corresponds to transitions from Œ©‚àó to Œ©‚àñŒ©‚àó, we see that after a suitable permutation of its rows and columns P can be written as

P=[AB0I].

Here I is the identity matrix, since we assume that the particle stops after reaching a flawless state.

Let Œ∏=[Œ∏1‚à£Œ∏2] be the row vector that corresponds to the probability distribution of the starting state, where Œ∏1 and Œ∏2 are the vectors that correspond to states in Œ©‚àó and Œ©‚àñŒ©‚àó, respectively. Then the probability that after t steps the particle is still inside Œ©‚àó is exactly ‚à•Œ∏1At‚à•1. Therefore, for any initial distribution Œ∏, the particle escapes Œ©‚àó if and only if the spectral radius, œÅ(A), of A is strictly less than 1. Moreover, the rate of convergence is dictated by 1‚àíœÅ(A). Unfortunately, since A is huge and defined implicitly as an algorithm, œÅ(A) is not readily available.

To overcome this obstacle in linear systems analysis, one typically bounds an operator norm ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à• of the matrix A, possibly after a change of basis A‚Ä≤=MAM‚àí1, since œÅ(A)=œÅ(A‚Ä≤)‚â§‚à•A‚Ä≤‚à• for any such norm. As a simple example of this idea in action, we first show how it can be used to capture the classical potential argument. Consider any potential function œï on Œ© such that œï(œÉ)>0 for œÉ‚ààŒ©‚àó, while œï(œÉ)=0 for œÉ‚àâŒ©‚àó. (So, in our k-SAT example, œï(œÉ) could be the number of violated clauses in assignment œÉ.) The potential argument establishes that, if œï is reduced in expectation at every step, i.e., if for every œÉ‚ààŒ©‚àó,

‚àëœÉ‚Ä≤‚ààŒ©P[œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤](œï(œÉ‚Ä≤)‚àíœï(œÉ))<0, (2)

then the particle must eventually escape Œ©‚àó. To express this argument via norms, let A‚Ä≤=MAM‚àí1, where M is the diagonal |Œ©‚àó|√ó|Œ©‚àó| matrix diag(œï(œÉ)‚àí1). Observe that A‚Ä≤[œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤]=A[œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤]œï(œÉ‚Ä≤)/œï(œÉ). Recalling that ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à•‚àû is the maximum row sum of a matrix, we see that (2) is equivalent to ‚à•A‚Ä≤‚à•‚àû<1.

To illustrate the power of this approach, we now show how typical algorithmic LLL arguments amount to bounding the spectral radius in terms of the ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à•1 norm, i.e., the dual of the ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à•‚àû norm above. As a simple example, consider the Moser-Tardos algorithm applied to k-SAT formulas. Let F={c1,‚Ä¶,cm} be a k-SAT formula on n variables, let Œ©={0,1}n be the set of all possible truth assignments, and Œ©‚àó the set of non-satisfying assignments. Recall the definition of the Moser-Tardos algorithm, and assume for simplicity that we resample the lowest indexed violated clause in each step, so that the algorithm is a Markov chain. Finally, for each clause ci, let Ai be the |Œ©‚àó|√ó|Œ©‚àó| matrix whose non-zero entries Ai[œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤] equal 12k and correspond to transitions œÉ‚ÜíœÉ‚Ä≤ where ci is the lowest indexed violated clause in œÉ, and œÉ‚Ä≤ is obtained from œÉ by changing the values of a subset of the variables in ci. Thus, A=‚àëci‚ààFAi. Recalling that the ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à•1 norm equals the maximum column sum, we see that ‚à•Ai‚à•1=12k, since each column œÉ‚Ä≤ of Ai has exactly one non-zero entry A[œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤], where œÉ is derived by mutating the variables of ci in œÉ‚Ä≤ to the unique combination violating ci. Therefore, for any number of steps t, we see that

(3)

where Wt is the set of all t-sequences of clause indices W=(w1,w2,‚Ä¶,wt), usually called witness sequences, that may occur as the first t resampled clauses in an execution of the algorithm. Crucial for deriving the second inequality in (3) is the submultiplicativity of operator norms, allowing us to bound the norm of each of the |Wt| products of t matrices by the product of their norms. The proof is concluded via a (by now standard) argument showing that, if each clause shares variables with at most Œî other clauses (the standard LLL condition), then |Wt|‚â§2m(eŒî)t. Therefore, if Œî‚â§(1‚àíœµ)2k/e, the probability that the algorithm fails to find a satisfying assignment within t steps is at most œÅ(At)‚â§2m(1‚àíœµ)t‚Üí0, for suitable t=Œ©(m). In other words, the algorithm finds a satisfying assignment in linear time with high probability.

A very similar argument can be used to capture even the most general existing versions of the algorithmic LLL [3, 32, 2, 37], which are described by arbitrary flaws and, for each flaw fi, an arbitrary corresponding transition matrix Ai for addressing the flaw. Note that (3) is in essence a weighted counting of witness sequences, the weight of each sequence being the product of the norms ‚à•Awi‚à•1. Observe also that in our k-SAT example above, the only probabilistic notion was the transition matrix A and we did not make any implicit or explicit reference to a probability measure Œº. To cast general algorithmic LLL arguments in this same form, any measure Œº is incorporated as a change of basis for the transition matrix A, i.e., we bound ‚à•A‚Ä≤‚à•1=‚à•MAM‚àí1‚à•1 as ‚àëW‚ààWt‚àèti=1‚à•MAwiM‚àí1‚à•1, where M is the diagonal |Œ©‚àó|√ó|Œ©‚àó| matrix diag(Œº(œÉ)), similarly to the potential function argument. We thus see that the measure Œº is nothing other than a tool for analyzing the progress of the algorithm.

Our main theorem.

The matrix-norm perspective we introduce in this paper allows us not only to cast the probabilistic method aspect of the algorithmic LLL as a change of basis, and the overall approach as a dual potential function argument, but, more importantly, to significantly expand and refine the analysis, so that it can avoid a hard notion of dependence, i.e., a dependency or causality graph. This is because, unlike all past works, the notion of interaction between events/flaws, can now be made soft i.e., non-binary, so that interactions can be arbitrarily dense as long as they are sufficiently weak.

More formally, identifying flaws fi with their indices i, when the algorithm addresses flaw i in state œÉ, it moves to a new state œÉ‚Ä≤ according to a probability distribution œÅi(œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤). (We make only minimal assumptions on the choice of which flaw to address; e.g., it suffices to assume that the algorithm chooses the flaw of lowest index according to some arbitrary permutation.) For each flaw i and subset S‚äÜ[m] of flaws, let ASi be the |Œ©|√ó|Œ©| matrix whose non-zero entries ASi[œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤]=œÅi(œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤) correspond to transitions in which addressing flaw i introduces every flaw in S (and perhaps more). These new matrices ASi will play a crucial role in our analysis, where as discussed above, the key quantity will be the norm ‚à•MASiM‚àí1‚à• (for any operator norm ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à• and any invertible matrix M, viewed as before as a change of basis); we refer to this quantity as the charge Œ≥Si of the pair (i,S). We can now informally state our main theorem, which gives a criterion for convergence of the local search algorithm.

Theorem 1.1.

If there exist positive real numbers {œài}mi=1 such that for all i‚àà[m],

1œài‚àëS‚äÜ[m]Œ≥Si‚àèj‚ààSœàj<1, (4)

then the above algorithm finds a flawless object efficiently with high probability.

For a more precise statement of this theorem see Section 3, where in particular we quantify the running time; in typical applications, the phrase ‚Äúefficiently‚Äù means in time linear in the input size.

Observe that Theorem 1.1 is a strict generalization of the algorithmic LLL condition (1). To see this, we recall that the quantity Œ≥i in (1) is defined in [2, 37] as

Œ≥i=maxœÉ‚Ä≤1Œº(œÉ‚Ä≤)‚àëœÉŒº(œÉ)œÅi(œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤),

which is nothing other than ‚à•MAiM‚àí1‚à•1, with M=diag(Œº(œÉ)) and Ai=A‚àÖi, i.e., the transition matrix for flaw i with no restriction on S. As a result, Œ≥i=Œ≥‚àÖi‚â•Œ≥Si for all S, while Œ≥Si=0 for S‚äàŒì(i), so that the lhs of (4) is always at most that of (1). (Note that this is with the ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à•1 norm in the definition of Œ≥Si. Theorem 1.1 allows us to use other norms as well, which may do even better.) We further explain how our main theorem compares to previous algorithmic LLL conditions in Appendix A.

The comparison above reveals where the improvement in Theorem 1.1 comes from: the new theorem handles the interactions between flaws in the dynamics by assigning different weights Œ≥Si to flaw i according to the set S of flaws introduced when addressing i. In contrast, previous versions of the (algorithmic) LLL assign a uniform weight Œ≥i=maxSŒ≥Si to a flaw whenever it appears. (In the proof of Theorem 1.1, crucially, the notion of a witness sequence as a sequence of flaws addressed by the algorithm is replaced by the more detailed notion of a sequence of addressed flaws together with the sets of flaws they introduce.) In this sense we may view Theorem 1.1 as a ‚Äúsoftcore‚Äù version of the algorithmic LLL because it quantifies the strengths of the interactions between flaws, replacing the rather crude binary relation induced by the causality graph. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first condition of this type.

Theorem 1.1 has a heuristic interpretation as a potential argument, which we briefly sketch. For arbitrary {œái}mi=1>1, let us define the potential of any state œÉ to be œï(œÉ)=‚àèi‚ààU(œÉ)œái, where U(œÉ) denotes the set of flaws present in state œÉ, so that œï(œÉ)‚â•1 with equality iff œÉ is flawless. If we set œài=œáiŒ≥‚àÖi>0, then (4) reads

1œái‚àëS‚äÜ[m]ŒªSi‚àèj‚ààSœáj<1, (5)

where ŒªSi:=(Œ≥Si/Œ≥‚àÖi)‚àèj‚ààSŒ≥‚àÖj. Loosely, we may interpret ŒªSi as an upper bound on the probability of introducing the set of flaws S when addressing flaw i, in which case, (5) asserts that ‚Äúaddressing any flaw i must decrease the potential on average.‚Äù This intuition, while not entirely rigorous, informs the design and analysis of several of our algorithms using Theorem 1.1.

Applications.

Theorem 1.1 provides a unifying framework for the analysis of essentially all currently known LLL/entropic method inspired algorithms, and opens up the possibility of design and analysis of new algorithms. We illustrate the scope of the theorem in three different ways:

  1. Graph coloring: We give a new bound for the chromatic number of graphs with sparse neighborhoods, improving a classical result by Alon, Krivelevich and Sudakov [7]. Even though our bound applies to arbitrary graphs, it matches the factor of 2 algorithmic barrier for the chromatic number of random graphs. Thus, any improvement of our bound would be a major breakthrough in random graph theory.

    Theorem 1.2.

    Let G be a graph with maximum degree Œî in which the neighbors of every vertex span at most Œî2/f edges. For all œµ>0, there exist Œîœµ,fœµ such that if Œî‚â•Œîœµ and f‚àà[fœµ,Œî2+1], then

    œá(G)‚â§(2+œµ)Œî/ln‚àöf. (6)

    Furthermore, such a coloring can be found in polynomial time with high probability. Moreover, if f‚àà[Œî2+2œµ1+2œµ(lnŒî)2,Œî2+1] then (2+œµ) can be replaced by (1+œµ).

    We prove our bound by analyzing a complex local search algorithm, inspired by [38], that backtracks not only from ‚Äúdead ends‚Äù, but also from ‚Äúunfavorable‚Äù regions of state space. The complexity of the algorithm comes from the fact that is a ‚Äúhybrid‚Äù algorithm, in the sense that it incorporates ideas both from ‚Äúresampling‚Äù local search algorithms, i.e., algorithms like the Moser-Tardos algorithm, and backtracking algorithms (as we discuss below). To the best of our knowledge hybrid local search algorithms have not been analyzed in the past. We consider equally important that we derived our algorithm by taking the aforementioned heuristic interpretation of (5) in terms of the quantities ŒªSi at face value and reverse-engineering the algorithm‚Äôs choices so that the potential does indeed decrease on average in every step. The fact that Theorem 1.1 establishes the convergence of this algorithm in a black box fashion, i.e., by simply computing the charges of the different flaws, is testament to its flexibility. We formally present these results in Section 3.2 and prove them in Section 6.

  2. Backtracking algorithms: Starting with [26] there has been a long sequence of papers [21, 19, 24, 25, 43, 45, 15, 38, 8, 13] that analyze a class of backtracking algorithms for constraint satisfaction problems via the entropy compression method, a technique developed by Moser [40] in his original work to make the LLL constructive for k-SAT. While there have been attempts to approach backtracking algorithms systematically [21, 25], this important class of local search algorithms typically requires quite sophisticated ad-hoc machinery for its analysis. As we shall see in Section 3.3, Theorem 1.1 is able to handle backtracking algorithms (and indeed all applications of the entropy compression method) seamlessly. For example, it makes the analysis of the following natural algorithm under the LLL conditions trivial.

    We demonstrate this in Section 5, along with an analogous result for Acyclic Edge Coloring.

  3. Distributional properties: It is often useful to obtain more detailed information about the execution of a stochastic local search algorithm, such as the number of possible distinct outputs, or the probability that certain portions of the state space are visited. This information is available for the Moser-Tardos algorithm due to Haeupler, Saha and Srinivasan [27] and Harris and Srinivasan [31], and for general stochastic local search algorithms due to Iliopoulos [33] under a combinatorial notion of ‚Äúcommutativity‚Äù introduced by Kolmogorov [37]. Our new framework provides a very natural and more general notion of commutativity (essentially matrix commutativity) which allows us to recover all these results with much simpler proofs. We present these results in Section 3.4 and prove them in Section 7.

2 Background and Preliminaries

2.1 Flaws and Actions

Let Œ© be a discrete state space, and let F={f1,f2,‚Ä¶,fm} be a collection of subsets (flaws) of Œ© such that ‚ãÉi‚àà[m]fi=Œ©‚àó. Our goal is to find a state œÉ‚ààŒ©‚àñŒ©‚àó; we refer to such states as ‚Äúflawless.‚Äù

For a state œÉ, we denote by U(œÉ)={j‚àà[m] s.t. fj‚àãœÉ} the set of flaws present in œÉ. We consider local search algorithms working on Œ© which, in each flawed state œÉ‚ààŒ©‚àó, choose a flaw fi in U(œÉ) and randomly move to a nearby state in an effort to fix fi. We will assume that for every flaw fi and every state œÉ‚ààfi there is a non-empty set of actions a(i,œÉ)‚äÜŒ© such that addressing flaw fi in state œÉ amounts to selecting the next state œÉ‚Ä≤ from a(i,œÉ) according to some probability distribution œÅi(œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤). Note that potentially a(i,œÉ)‚à©fi‚â†‚àÖ, i.e., addressing a flaw does not necessarily imply removing it. However, we do require that for every state œÉ‚ààfi we have a(i,œÉ)‚â†{œÉ}.

Throughout the paper we consider algorithms that start from a state œÉ‚ààŒ© picked from an initial distribution Œ∏, and then repeatedly pick a flaw that is present in the current state and address it. The algorithm always terminates when it encounters a flawless state. Our goal is to give conditions under which such an algorithm terminates quickly with high probability.

2.2 The Lov√°sz Local Lemma

To prove the existence of flawless objects we can often use the Probabilistic Method. As a matter of fact, in many interesting cases, this is the only way we know how to do so. To employ the Probabilistic Method, we introduce a probability measure Œº over Œ© and consider the collection of ‚Äúbad‚Äù events corresponding to flaws. If we are able to show that the probability to avoid all bad events is strictly positive, then this implies the existence of a flawless object. A trivial example is the case where all the bad events are independent of one another and none of them has probability one. One of the most powerful tools of the Probabilistic Method is the Lov√°sz Local Lemma [20] which weakens the latter restrictive condition of independence to a condition of limited dependence.

General LLL.

Let (Œ©,Œº) be a probability space and B={B1,B2,‚Ä¶,Bm} be a set of m (bad) events. For each i‚àà[m], let D(i)‚äÜ[m]‚àñ{i} be such that Œº(Bi‚à£‚à©j‚ààS¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬ØBj)=Œº(Bi) for every S‚äÜ[m]‚àñ(D(i)‚à™{i}). If there exist positive real numbers {œài}mi=1 such that for all i‚àà[m],

Œº(Bi)œài‚àëS‚äÜD(i)‚à™{i}‚àèj‚ààSœàj‚â§1, (7)

then the probability that none of the events in B occurs is at least ‚àèmi=11/(1+œài)>0.

Remark 2.1.

Condition (7) above is equivalent to the more well-known form Œº(Bi)‚â§xi‚àèj‚ààD(i)(1‚àíxj), where xi=œài/(1+œài).

2.3 Matrices and Norms

Let ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à• be any norm over vectors in Rn. The dual norm, also over vectors in Rn, is defined as

‚à•z‚à•‚àó=sup‚à•x‚à•=1|z‚ä§x|.

For example, the dual norm of ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à•‚àû is ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à•1. It can be seen that ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à•‚àó‚àó=‚à•‚ãÖ‚à• and that for any vectors x,z,

z‚ä§x=‚à•x‚à•(z‚ä§x‚à•x‚à•)‚â§‚à•z‚à•‚àó‚à•x‚à•. (8)

The corresponding operator norm, over n√ón real matrices, is defined as

‚à•A‚à•‚â°sup‚à•x‚à•=1‚à•Ax‚à•.

For example, if A is a matrix with non-negative entries then ‚à•A‚à•‚àû and ‚à•A‚à•1 can be seen to be the maximum row and column sum of A, respectively. Operator norms are submultiplicative, i.e., for every operator norm ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à• and any two n√ón matrices A,B,

‚à•AB‚à•‚â§‚à•A‚à•‚à•B‚à•. (9)

Finally, for any vector norm ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à•, any row vector x‚ä§ and n√ón matrix A we have that

‚à•x‚ä§A‚à•‚àó‚â§‚à•x‚ä§‚à•‚àó‚à•A‚à•. (10)

3 Statement of Results

3.1 A ‚ÄúSoft‚Äù Algorithmic LLL Criterion

In this section we restate our main theorem, Theorem 1.1, more precisely (Theorem 3.1 below).

Let œÄ be an arbitrary permutation over m. We say that the algorithm follows the œÄ-strategy if at each step it picks to address the flaw corresponding to the lowest index element of U(œÉ) according to œÄ.

For each flaw index i‚àà[m] and for each subset S‚äÜ[m], let ASi be the |Œ©|√ó|Œ©| matrix defined by ASi[œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤]=œÅi(œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤) if œÉ‚ààfi and S‚äÜU(œÉ‚Ä≤)‚àñ(U(œÉ)‚àñ{i}), and ASi[œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤]=0 otherwise.

For a state œÉ, let eœÉ denote the indicator vector of œÉ, i.e., eœÉ[œÉ]=1 and eœÉ[œÑ]=0 for all œÑ‚ààŒ©‚àñ{œÉ}. For a fixed operator norm ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à• and invertible matrix M such that ‚àëœÉ‚ààŒ©‚à•MeœÉ‚à•=1, we define the charge of the pair (i,S) to be Œ≥Si=‚à•MASiM‚àí1‚à•. Finally, the span of a probability distribution Œ∏:Œ©‚Üí[0,1], denoted by Span(Œ∏), is the set of flaw indices that may be present in a state selected according to Œ∏, i.e., Span(Œ∏)=‚ãÉœÉ‚ààŒ©:Œ∏(œÉ)>0U(œÉ).

Theorem 3.1.

If there exist positive real numbers {œài}i‚àà[m] such that for every i‚àà[m],

Œ∂i:=1œài‚éõ‚éù‚àëS‚äÜ[m]Œ≥Si‚àèj‚ààSœàj‚éû‚é†<1, (11)

then, for every permutation œÄ over [m], the probability that the algorithm following the œÄ-strategy fails to find a flawless object within T0+sŒ¥ steps is 2‚àís, where Œ¥=1‚àímaxi‚àà[m]Œ∂i, and

T0=log2‚à•Œ∏‚ä§M‚àí1‚à•‚àó+log2‚éõ‚éù‚àëS‚äÜSpan(Œ∏)‚àèj‚ààSœàj‚éû‚é†+log2(maxS‚äÜ[m]1‚àèj‚ààSœàj).

To interpret the theorem we start by noting that in typical applications, e.g., in all LLL applications, the sum in (11) is easily computable as Œ≥Si=0 for the vast majority of subsets S. For the running time bound, note first that the sum of the second and third terms in T0 is at most mlog2(1+œàmaxœàmin), which is typically O(m). For the first term, in applications M will usually be a diagonal matrix diag(Œº(œÉ)), and the condition ‚àëœÉ‚ààŒ©‚à•MeœÉ‚à•=1 means that Œº is a probability distribution. Thus the vector Œ∏‚ä§M‚àí1 is the ratio of two probability distributions on Œ©, and its norm is typically at most Œº‚àí1min where Œºmin=minœÉŒº(œÉ). In applications, Œºmin will usually be some constant times 1/|Œ©|, so that log2‚à•Œ∏‚ä§M‚àí1‚à•‚àó=O(log|Œ©|). Hence in most applications T0=O(log|Œ©|+m), which is typically linear in the input size. Finally, we will sometimes use the term ‚Äúthe algorithm terminates efficiently with high probability‚Äù as a shorthand for the running time bound of Theorem 3.1.

Remark 3.1.

The requirement ‚àëœÉ‚ààŒ©‚à•MeœÉ‚à•=1 is not really necessary. We impose it because in applications M is typically diagonal with positive entries, in which case the normalization ‚àëœÉ‚ààŒ©‚à•MeœÉ‚à•=1 simplifies the expressions for the running time.

Remark 3.2.

For any fixed permutation œÄ, the charges Œ≥Si can be reduced by replacing ASi with the matrix ASi(œÄ) that results by zeroing out every row œÉ of ASi for which i is not the lowest indexed element of U(œÉ) according to œÄ.

Remark 3.3.

Theorem 3.1 holds also for algorithms using flaw choice strategies other than œÄ-strategies. We discuss some such strategies in Section 4.4. However, there is good reason to expect that it does not hold for arbitrary flaw choice strategies, i.e., without additional assumptions (for more details see [37]).

3.2 Application to Coloring Graphs

In graph coloring one is given a graph G(V,E) and the goal is to find a mapping of V to a set of q colors so that no edge in E is monochromatic. The chromatic number, œá(G), of G is the smallest integer q for which this is possible. Our main result in this section concerns the chromatic number of graphs, as a function of the maximum degree and the maximum number of triangles in any neighborhood. Observe that when f=Œî2+1 in Theorem 3.2 below, the graph is triangle-free.

Theorem 3.2.

Let G be a graph with maximum degree Œî in which the neighbors of every vertex span at most Œî2/f edges. For all œµ>0, there exist Œîœµ,fœµ such that if Œî‚â•Œîœµ and f‚àà[fœµ,Œî2+1], then

œá(G)‚â§(2+œµ)Œî/ln‚àöf. (12)

Furthermore, such a coloring can be found in polynomial time with high probability. Moreover, if f‚àà[Œî2+2œµ1+2œµ(lnŒî)2,Œî2+1] then (2+œµ) can be replaced by (1+œµ).

Theorem 3.2 improves a classical result of Alon, Krivelevich and Sudakov [7] which established (12) with an unspecified (large) constant in place of 2+œµ. In addition, random graphs suggest that the ‚Äúsparse case‚Äù of Theorem 3.2 is sharp, i.e., that no efficient algorithm can color graphs satisfying the conditions of the theorem with (1‚àíœµ)Œî/ln‚àöf colors. More precisely, Corollary 3.3 below, proved in Appendix D, implies that any such algorithm would be coloring random graphs using fewer than twice as many colors as their chromatic number. This would be a major (and unexpected) breakthrough in random graph theory, as beating this factor of 2 has been an elusive goal for over 40 years (also, for bounded [average] degree random graphs, this factor of 2 corresponds to a phase transition in the geometry of the set of colorings [1]).

Corollary 3.3.

For every œµ>0 and d‚àà(dœµlnn,(nlnn)13), there exist Œî=Œî(d,œµ) and f=f(d,œµ) such that with probability tending to 1 as n‚Üí‚àû, a random graph G=G(n,d/n) satisfies the conditions of Theorem 3.2 and œá(G)‚â•(12‚àíœµ)Œî/ln‚àöf.

Independently of whether Theorem 3.2 is tight or not, we find it remarkable that using only the assumption of sparse depth-one neighborhoods suffices to bring the chromatic number of arbitrary graphs within a factor of 2 of the chromatic number of random graphs and within parity in terms of efficient computation.

The key subroutine of our algorithm is a complex local search list-coloring algorithm. Recall that given a set Lv of colors (called a list) for each vertex v, a list-coloring maps each v‚ààV to a color in Lv so that no edge in E is monochromatic. A graph is q-list-colorable if it has a list-coloring no matter how one assigns a list of q colors to each vertex. The list chromatic number, œá‚Ñì(G), is the smallest q for which G is q-list-colorable. A celebrated result of Johansson established that there exists a large constant C>0 such that every triangle-free graph with maximum degree Œî‚â•Œî0 can be list-colored using CŒî/lnŒî colors. Very recently, using the entropy compression method, Molloy [38] improved Johansson‚Äôs result, replacing C with (1+œµ) for any œµ>0 and all Œî‚â•Œîœµ. (Soon after, Bernshteyn [11] established the same bound for the list chromatic number via the LLL, but his result is not constructive as it uses a complex probability measure for which it is not at all clear how one could design ‚Äúefficient‚Äù resampling oracles [32].) Our algorithm is a generalization of Molloy‚Äôs to the case of a bounded number of triangles per vertex and in Section 6 we establish the following general theorem for the list chromatic number (the triangle-free case corresponding to f=Œî2+1).

Theorem 3.4.

Let G be any graph with maximum degree Œî in which the neighbors of every vertex span at most Œî2/f edges. For all œµ>0, there exists Œîœµ such that if Œî‚â•Œîœµ and f‚àà[Œî2+2œµ1+2œµ(lnŒî)2,Œî2+1], then

œá‚Ñì(G)‚â§(1+œµ)Œî/ln‚àöf.

Furthermore, such a coloring can be found in polynomial time with high probability.

Armed with Theorem 3.4 we prove Theorem 3.2 by closely following the analysis of [7]. The main idea of the latter is to break down the input graph into triangle-free subgraphs, and color each one of them separately using distinct sets of colors by applying the result of Johanson [34]. Instead, we break down the graph into subgraphs with few triangles per neighborhood, and use Theorem 3.4 to color the pieces. The proof of Theorem 3.2 can be found in Section C of the Appendix.

Finally, we note that Vu [47] proved the analogue of the main result of [7] (again with a large constant) for the list chromatic number. While we don‚Äôt currently see how to sharpen Vu‚Äôs result to an analogue of Theorem 3.2 for the list chromatic number using our techniques, we note that our Theorem 3.4 improves over [47] for all f‚â•Œî2+2œµ1+2œµ(lnŒî)2.

3.3 Application to Backtracking Algorithms

We can get an important refinement of Theorem 3.1 for a special class of algorithms. In particular, assume that each flaw has the property that, once it is present, it can only be eradicated if the algorithm addresses it at a step of its execution (as opposed to its being eradicated ‚Äúcollaterally‚Äù by an action to address another flaw). Then, for each i‚àà[m] and S‚äÜ[m], one can replace ASi in the definition of Œ≥Si by the matrix CSi defined by CSi[œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤]=œÅi(œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤) if œÉ‚ààfi and S=U(œÉ‚Ä≤)‚àñ(U(œÉ)‚àñ{i}), and CSi[œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤]=0 otherwise. (Note the equality in S here!) Moreover, this also leads to an improvement in the running time bound of the algorithm, i.e., the value of T0 in Theorem 3.1. Specifically, if I(Œ∏) denotes the set of sets of indices of flaws that can be initially present after we sample from Œ∏, then we can replace the sum over S‚äÜSpan(Œ∏) by a sum over S‚ààI(Œ∏) in the second term of T0. The proof of these facts can be found in Section 4.3. As will be clear from the proof, one can get analogous refinements when only some of the flaws cannot be eradicated collaterally. Although it is perhaps counter-intuitive that avoiding ‚Äúcollateral fixes‚Äù can be beneficial to our analysis we note that a very similar phenomenon has been observed in practice [9].

An important class of algorithms that naturally avoid ‚Äúcollateral fixes‚Äù are backtracking algorithms, as mentioned in the introduction. In particular, consider a Constraint Satisfaction Problem (CSP) over a set of variables V={v1,v2‚Ä¶,vn}, each variable vi taking values in a domain Di, and a set of constraints C={c1,c2,‚Ä¶,cm} over these variables. The backtracking algorithms we consider operate as follows.

Notice that the algorithm above operates over partial non-violating assignments of the CSP and, thus, if it ever terminates, it finds a satisfying assignment. Moreover, observe that the DPLL algorithm for k-SAT we described in the introduction is an instantiation of this generic algorithm.

Let Œ© be the set of partial non-violating assignments for a given CSP. For each variable vi‚ààV, let flaw fi‚äÜŒ© comprise the assignments in which vi is unassigned. Clearly, each flaw fi can be only be removed by addressing it, as addressing any other flaw can only unassign vi. Thus, we can always take advantage of the above refinement when analyzing backtracking algorithms, a fact crucial in applications.

We give two representative applications in Section 5. First, we show that the very simple DPLL algorithm given in the introduction can capture the well-known application of the LLL to k-SAT. In fact, we develop a corollary of our main theorem that can be used to derive applications in the variable setting [41] via a backtracking algorithm, i.e., an algorithm of very different flavor from the Moser-Tardos algorithm. We note that Bissacot and Doin [13] also showed very recently and independently that backtracking algorithms can capture applications in the variable setting using the entropy compression method. Second, we show how our theorem can capture the main application of the generic approach of Esperet and Parreau [21] for analyzing backtracking algorithms for acyclic edge coloring. We then show how our analysis can be almost trivially adapted to make constructive an existential result of Bernshteyn [10] showing improved bounds for the acyclic chromatic index of graphs which do not contain any fixed arbitrary bipartite graph H.

3.4 Commutative Algorithms and Distributional Properties

Haeupler, Saha and Srinivasan [27] showed that the output of the Moser-Tardos algorithm well-approximates the conditional LLL-distribution ŒºLLL, i.e., the distribution obtained by conditioning on all bad events being avoided. In particular, they show that both distributions share the very powerful property that if a (not necessarily bad) event E is independent of most bad events, then its probability under either distribution is not much larger than it is under the unconditional measure Œº, per Proposition 3.5 below (stated for the LLL distribution). Building on this fact, [27] and follow-up works [31, 28, 29, 16] gave several new applications.

Proposition 3.5 ([27]).

If the LLL conditions (7) hold, then for any event E,

ŒºLLL(E)‚â§Œº(E)‚àëS‚äÜD(E)‚àèj‚ààSœàj,

where D(E)‚äÜ[m] is such that Œº(E‚à£‚ãÇj‚ààS¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬ØBj)=Œº(E) for all S‚äÜ[m]‚àñD(E).

Harvey and Vondr√°k [32] showed that these distributional results are unlikely to transfer to the more general algorithmic LLL settings of [3, 32, 2], because the so-called witness tree lemma, the key technical ingredient of the Moser-Tardos analysis, can fail in such settings. In [33], Iliopoulos established the witness tree lemma, from which the distributional result follow, for the ‚Äúcommutative setting‚Äù of Kolmogorov [37], which imposes mild restrictions on the frameworks of [3, 32, 2], satisfied by most LLL applications.

Here we establish the witness tree lemma for a generalization of Kolmogorov‚Äôs setting, which we call the commutative algorithms setting. Our notion of commutativity is based on matrix commutativity and, besides generalizing [37], it also leads to significantly simpler proofs than [37, 33], at the mild cost of slightly restricting the family of flaw choice strategies (in [37, 33] the flaw choice strategy can be arbitrary).

Definition 3.6.

A flaw choice strategy S is canonical if it can be expressed as a sequence (si)i‚â•1, where si:Œ©‚Üí[m] is a (possibly stochastic) function that takes as input the i-th state of the algorithm, œÉi, and outputs an element of U(œÉi).

Throughout this section we assume that our algorithms follow a canonical flaw choice strategy.

For i‚àà[m], let Ai:=A‚àÖi denote the |Œ©|√ó|Œ©| matrix defined by Ai[œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤]=œÅi(œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤) if œÉ‚ààfi, and Ai[œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤]=0 otherwise. Moreover, let Œì(i)={j‚àà[m] s.t. ‚àÉS‚àãj and Œ≥iS>0} be the set of indices of flaws that can potentially be introduced by addressing flaw i. Finally, for any symmetric, binary relation ‚àº over [m] we define N(i)={j s.t. i‚àºj}.

Definition 3.7.

An algorithm defined by a set of probability distributions {œÅi(œÉ,‚ãÖ),œÉ‚ààfi}mi=1 is commutative with respect to a symmetric binary relation ‚àº if

  1. For every i,j‚àà[m] such that i‚âÅj we have AiAj=AjAi;

  2. Œì(i)‚äÜN(i).

Remark 3.4.

We note that this is the only place where we require an explicit binary ‚Äúdependency‚Äù relation Œì(i). In most applications, the condition Œì(i)‚äÜN(i) is redundant because AiAj‚â†AjAi when i‚ààŒì(j).

Given an arbitrary set E‚äÜŒ© and a commutative algorithm A, consider an extension, AE, of A by defining an extra flaw fm+1‚â°E with its own set of probability distributions œÅm+1(œÉ,‚ãÖ),œÉ‚ààE. If A is commutative with respect to ‚àº, we will say that AE is a commutative extension of A if AE is also commutative with respect to ‚àº; that is, if the conditions of Definition 3.7 also hold for matrix AE‚â°Am+1 and sets N(E)‚â°N(m+1) and Œì(E)‚â°Œì(m+1).

As we will see, commutative extensions should be thought of as a tool to bound the probability that A ever reaches a subset E of the state space. That is, they are defined only for the purposes of the analysis and, typically in applications, they are a natural extension of the algorithm. For example, in the case of the Moser-Tardos algorithm applied to k-SAT, if one would like to bound the probability that the algorithm ever reaches a state such that variables x1,x2,x3 of the formula are all set to true, then one could define fm+1={œÉ‚ààŒ© s.t. œÉ(x1)=œÉ(x2)=œÉ(x3)=1} along with the corresponding commutative extension of the Moser-Tardos algorithm that addresses fm+1 by resampling variables x1,x2,x3 according to the product measure over the variables of the formula that the Moser-Tardos algorithm uses whenever it needs to resample a violated clause. Indeed, commutative extensions of this form are implicitly defined in the analysis of [27] for the Moser-Tardos algorithm.

We will use the notation Pr[‚ãÖ]=PrA[‚ãÖ] to refer to the probability of events in the probability space induced by the execution of algorithm A. For example, the probability that A reaches a set E‚äÜŒ© of the state space during its execution will be denoted by Pr[E]. Finally, for a fixed operator norm ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à• and invertible matrix M such that ‚àëœÉ‚ààŒ©‚à•MeœÉ‚à•=1 we define Œ≥i=Œ≥‚àÖi=‚à•MAiM‚àí1‚à• for each i‚àà[m].

Theorem 3.8.

Give a symmetric, binary relation ‚àº and a commutative algorithm A with respect to ‚àº, if there exist positive real numbers {œài}i‚àà[m] such that for every i‚àà[m],

Œ≥iœài‚àëS‚äÜN(i)‚àèj‚ààSœàj‚â§1,

then

  1. for each i‚àà[m], E[Ti]‚â§Œªinitœài ;

  2. for each E‚äÜŒ©, Pr[E]‚â§ŒªinitŒ≥E‚àëS‚äÜN(E)‚àèj‚ààSœàj;

where Ti is the number of times flaw fi is addressed, Œªinit=‚à•Œ∏‚ä§M‚àí1‚à•‚àó, and N(E) and Œ≥E are defined with respect to a fixed commutative extension AE.

Corollary 3.9.

Algorithm A terminates after O(Œªinit‚àëi‚àà[m]œài) steps in expectation.

In Section 7 we present the statement and the proof of the witness tree lemma that is required for the proof of Theorem 3.8. Given the witness tree lemma, the proof of Theorem 3.8 is identical to that of the analogous result in [33] and will be omitted for the sake of brevity. In [33] the reader can also see how to improve the bounds of Theorem 3.8 so that it captures the cluster expansion [14] criterion and Shearer‚Äôs criterion [46] for the LLL.

4 Proof of Main Theorem 3.1

In this section we present the proof of our main theorem, the new algorithmic LLL condition Theorem 3.1, along with some refinements.

4.1 Tracking the Set of Flaws Present

We say that a trajectory Œ£=(œÉ1,œÉ2,‚Ä¶,œÉt+1) followed by the algorithm is a bad t-trajectory if every state œÉi, i‚àà[t+1], is flawed. Thus, our goal is to bound the probability that the algorithm follows a bad t-trajectory.

Given a bad trajectory, intuitively, we track the flaws introduced into the state in each step, where a flaw is said to ‚Äúintroduce itself‚Äù whenever addressing it fails to remove it. Of the flaws introduced in each step, we disregard those that later get eradicated collaterally, i.e., by an action addressing some other flaw. The rest form the ‚Äúwitness sequence‚Äù of the trajectory, i.e., a sequence of sets of flaws.

Fix any permutation œÄ on [m]. For any S‚äÜ[m], let œÄ(S)=minj‚ààSœÄ(j), i.e., the lowest index in S according to œÄ. Recalling that U(œÉ) is the set of indices of flaws present in œÉ, in the following we assume that the index of the flaw addressed in state œÉ is œÄ(U(œÉ)), which we sometimes abbreviate as œÄ(œÉ). Also, to lighten notation, we will denote A‚àñ{œÄ(B)} by A‚àíœÄ(B).

Definition 4.1.

Let Œ£=(œÉ1,œÉ2,‚Ä¶,œÉt+1) be any bad t-trajectory. Let B0=U(œÉ1). For 1‚â§i‚â§t, let

A crucial feature of witness sequences is that they allow us to recover the sequence of flaws addressed.

4.3 Proof of Refinements of Theorem 3.1

Recall that a necessary condition for œï=(S0,S1,‚Ä¶,St) to be the witness sequence is Si‚äÜBi for 1‚â§i‚â§t. When flaws are never eradicated collaterally, i.e., Ci=‚àÖ always, it must be that Si=Bi for 1‚â§i‚â§t. But

Pr[t‚ãÄi=1((i)‚ààU(œÉi))t‚ãÄi=1(Si=Bi)‚ãÄœÉt+1=œÑ]=Œ∏‚ä§t‚àèi=1CSi(i)eœÑ, (23)

where CSi(i) are the sparser matrices defined in Section 3.3, yielding the improved condition for termination. Also, since C0=‚àÖ, it is also necessary that S0‚ààI(Œ∏), implying that only those equivalence classes of Ft with R‚ààI(Œ∏) contribute to the sum in (22), yielding the improved bound on the running time.

4.4 Other flaw choice strategies

The only place where we used the fact that the flaw choice is based on a fixed permutation was to assert, in Lemma 4.3, that the witness sequence of a trajectory determines the sequence of addressed flaws. Thus, our analysis is in fact valid for every flaw choice strategy that shares this property.

A first example of such a strategy is ‚Äúpick a random occurring flaw and address it‚Äù. To implement this, we can fix a priori an infinite sequence of uniformly random permutations œÄ1,œÄ2,‚Ä¶ and at the i-th step address the lowest indexed flaw present according to œÄi. It is straightforward to see that Lemma 4.3 still holds if we replace œÄ with œÄi therein and in Definition 4.2.

As a second example, consider the following recursive way to chose which flaw to address at each step (which makes the algorithm non-Markovian). The algorithm now maintains a stack. The flaws present in œÉ1, ordered according to some permutation œÄ, comprise the initial stack content. The algorithm starts by addressing the flaw at the top of the stack, i.e., œÄ(œÉ1), as before. Now, though, any flaws introduced in the i-th step, i.e., the elements of Bi, go on the top of the stack (ordered by œÄ), while all eradicated flaws are removed from the stack. The algorithm terminates when the stack empties. It is not hard to see that, by taking S0 to be the initial stack content, popping the flaw at the top of the stack at each step, and adding Si to the top of the stack (ordered by œÄ), the sequence of popped flaws is the sequence of addressed flaws.

5 Applications to Backtracking Algorithms

In this section we present two applications of our main theorem to analyze backtracking search algorithms. First, we prove a useful corollary of Theorem 3.1 that holds in the so-called variable setting, and use it to give an almost trivial analysis of the DPLL algorithm for k-SAT. Second, we analyze a backtracking algorithm for acyclic edge coloring that lies outside the variable setting. We emphasize that these analyses follow very easily from our framework.

5.1 The Variable Setting

In this section we show how we can use Theorem 3.1 to employ backtracking algorithms in order to capture applications in the variable setting, i.e., the setting considered by Moser and Tardos. In particular, we consider a product measure over variables V and define a bad event for each constraint c‚ààC being violated and show the following corollary of Theorem 3.1.

Theorem 5.1.

Let P be any product measure over a set of variables V and let Ac be the event that constraint c is violated. If there exist positive real numbers {œàv}v‚ààV such that for every variable v‚ààV,

1œàv(1+‚àëc‚àãvP(Ac)‚àèu‚ààcœàu)<1, (24)

then there exists a backtracking algorithm that finds a satisfying assignment efficiently with high probability.

We now use Theorem 5.1 to capture a well-known application of the Lov√°sz Local Lemma to sparse k-SAT formulas when P is the uniform measure. For a k-SAT formula Œ¶ we will be denoting its maximum degree as Œî‚â°Œî(Œ¶), i.e., each variable of Œ¶ is contained in at most Œî clauses.

Theorem 5.2.

Every k-SAT formula Œ¶ with maximum degree Œî<2kek is satisfiable. Moreover, there exists a backtracking algorithm that finds a satisfying assignment of Œ¶ efficiently.

Proof.

Setting œàv=œà=2Œ±>0 we see that it suffices to find a value Œ±>0 such that

which is feasible whenever

Œî<maxŒ±>02Œ±‚àí1Œ±k=2kk‚ãÖ(1‚àí1k)k‚àí1‚â§2kek.

‚àé

Remark 5.1.

In [22] it is shown that using a non-uniform product measure P one can improve the bound of Theorem 5.2 to Œî<2k+1e(k+1) and that this is asymptotically tight. We note that we can achieve the same bound using Theorem 5.1 with the same P but since this an involved LLL application we will not explicitly present it here.

5.2 Acyclic Edge Coloring

An edge-coloring of a graph is proper if all edges incident to each vertex have distinct colors. A proper edge coloring is acyclic if it has no bichromatic cycles, i.e., no cycle receives exactly two (alternating) colors. The smallest number of colors for which a graph G has an acyclic edge-coloring is denoted by œá‚Ä≤a(G).

Acyclic Edge Coloring (AEC) was originally motivated by the work of Coleman et al. [18, 17] on the efficient computation of Hessians and, since then, there has been a series of papers [6, 39, 42, 27, 36, 21] that upper bound œá‚Ä≤a(G) for graphs with bounded degree. The current best result was given recently by Giotis et al. in [23] who showed that œá‚Ä≤a(G)‚â§3.74Œî in graphs with maximum degree Œî.

A Simple Backtracking Algorithm

We show how one can apply Theorem 3.1 to recover the main application of the framework of [21] with a shorter proof.

Let G be a graph with m edges E={e1,‚Ä¶,em} and suppose we have q available colors.

Definition 5.4.

Given a graph G=(V,E) and a (possibly partial) edge-coloring of G, say that color c is 4-forbidden for e‚ààE if assigning c to e would result in either a violation of proper-edge-coloration, or a bichromatic 4-cycle containing e. Say that c is 4-available if it is not 4-forbidden.

Lemma 5.5 ([21]).

In any proper edge-coloring of G at most 2(Œî‚àí1) colors are 4-forbidden for any e‚ààE.

Proof.

The 4-forbidden colors for e={u,v} can be enumerated as: (i) the colors on edges adjacent to u, and (ii) for each edge ev adjacent to v, either the color of ev (if no edge with that color is adjacent to u), or the color of some edge e‚Ä≤ which together with e,ev and an edge adjacent to u form a cycle of length 4. ‚àé

Consider the following backtracking algorithm for Acyclic Edge Coloring with q=2(Œî‚àí1)+Q colors. At each step, choose the lowest indexed uncolored edge e and attempt to color it choosing uniformly at random among the 4-available colors for e. If one or more bichromatic cycles are created, then choose the lowest indexed one of them, say C={ei1,ei2,‚Ä¶,ei2‚Ñì=e}, and remove the colors from all its edges except ei1 and ei2.

The main result of [21] states the following.

Theorem 5.6.

Every graph G admits an acyclic edge coloring with q>4(Œî‚àí1) colors. Moreover, such a coloring can be found in O(|V|+|E|) time with high probability.

Proof.

Let Œ© be the set of partial acyclic edge colorings of G. For each edge e let fe be the subset (flaw) of Œ© that contains the partial acyclic edge colorings of G in which e is uncolored. We will apply Theorem 3.1 using the ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à•1 norm and M=1|Œ©|.

We first compute the charges Œ≥Se for each edge e and set of edges S. Notice that for Œ≥Se to be non-zero, it should either be that S=‚àÖ, or that S contains e and there exists a cycle C={ei1,ei2}‚à™S so that, when a recoloring of e makes C bichromatic, the backtracking step uncolors precisely the edges in S. With that in mind, for each edge e and each set S that contains e, let Ce(S) denote the set of cycles with the latter property.

Lemma 5.7.

For each edge e:

Œ≥Se=‚éß‚é™ ‚é™ ‚é™ ‚é™‚é®‚é™ ‚é™ ‚é™ ‚é™‚é©1Qif S=‚àÖ|Ce(S)|Qif e‚ààS0otherwise.,
Proof.

Notice that

Œ≥Se=maxœÉ‚Ä≤‚ààŒ©‚àëœÉ‚ààfeS=U(œÉ‚Ä≤)‚àñ(U(œÉ)‚àñ{e})œÅe(œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤)‚â§maxœÉ‚Ä≤‚ààŒ©‚àëœÉ‚ààfeS=U(œÉ‚Ä≤)‚àñ(U(œÉ)‚àñ{e})1Q,

since according to Lemma 5.5 œÅe(œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤)‚â§1Q for each pair (œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤)‚ààfe√óŒ©. The proof follows by observing that for each state œÉ‚Ä≤:

‚àé

An Application of the Local Cut Lemma

In [12] Bernshteyn introduced a non-constructive generalized LLL criterion, called the ‚ÄúLocal Cut Lemma‚Äù, with the aim of to drawing connections between the LLL and the entropy compression method. He later applied it in [10] to the problem of Acyclic Edge Coloring giving improved bounds assuming further constraints on the graph besides sparsity. For example he proved the following.

Theorem 5.8 ([10]).

Let G be a graph with maximum degree Œî and let H be a fixed bipartite graph. If G does not contain H as a subgraph, then there exists an acyclic edge coloring of G using at most 3(Œî+o(1)) colors.

We now show how to use our framework to give a constructive proof of Theorem 5.8. This will follow immediately from the following structural lemma in [10].

Lemma 5.9 ([10]).

There exist positive constants Œ≥,Œ¥ such that the following holds. Let G be a graph with maximum degree Œî that does not contain H as a subgraph. Then for any edge e‚ààE(G) and for any integer k‚â•4, the number of cycles of length k in G that contain e is at most Œ≥Œîk‚àí2‚àíŒ¥.

Constructive proof of Theorem 5.8.

Notice that in this case almost identical calculations to those above, invoking Lemma 5.9 to upper bound the number of cycles that contain e and setting œà=cŒ± we obtain

1œàe(‚àëS‚äÜEŒ≥Se‚àèh‚ààSœàh)‚â§minœà‚àà(1,c)(1œà+(œà)3Œ≥Œî‚àíŒ¥c2(c2‚àíœà2))=1cminŒ±>1(Œ±+Œ±Œ≥Œî‚àíŒ¥Œ±(Œ±2‚àí1)).

Thus, as Œî grows, the value of c required for the algorithm to terminate approaches 1, concluding the proof. ‚àé

6 Graph Coloring Proofs

6.1 The Algorithm

To prove Theorem 3.4 we will generalize the algorithm of Molloy [38] for coloring triangle-free graphs. A straightforward generalization of Molloy‚Äôs algorithm would introduce monochromatic edges when the neighborhood of a vertex is recolored. However, the presence of even a few monochromatic edges causes the analysis to fail. To get around this problem, we introduce backtracking steps into the algorithm. The analysis of this more complicated algorithm is enabled by our new convergence criterion,Theorem 3.1.

For each vertex v‚ààV, let Nv denote the neighbors of v and let Ev={{u1,u2}:u1,u2‚ààNv} denote the edges spanned by them. Recall that the color-list of v is denoted by Lv. It will be convenient to treat Blank also as a color. Indeed, the initial distribution Œ∏ of our algorithm assigns all its probability mass to the state where every vertex is colored Blank. Whenever assigning a color to a vertex creates monochromatic edges, the algorithm will immediately uncolor enough vertices so that no monochromatic edge remains. Edges with two Blank endpoints are not considered monochromatic. To uncolor a vertex v, the algorithm picks a monochromatic edge e incident to v and assigns e to v instead of a color, thus also creating a record of the reason for the uncoloring. Thus,

Œ©‚äÜ‚àèv‚ààV{Lv‚à™{Blank}‚à™Ev}.

Let L=(1+œµ)Œîlnff‚àí12+2œµ and assume Œî is sufficiently large so that L‚â•10.

The Flaws

We let Lv(œÉ)‚äÜ(Lv‚à™{Blank}) be the set of colors we can assign to v in state œÉ without creating any monochromatic edge. We call these the available colors for v in œÉ and note that Blank is always available. For each v‚ààV, we define a flaw expressing that there are ‚Äútoo few available colors for v,‚Äù namely

Bv={œÉ‚ààŒ©:|Lv(œÉ)|<L}.

For each color c other than Blank, let Tv,c(œÉ) be the set of Blank neighbors of v for which c is available in œÉ, i.e., the vertices that may ‚Äúcompete‚Äù with v for color c. For each v‚ààV, we define a flaw expressing that there is ‚Äútoo much competition for v‚Äôs available (real) colors,‚Äù namely

Zv=‚éß‚é®‚é©œÉ‚ààŒ©:‚àëc‚ààLv(œÉ)‚àñBlank|Tv,c(œÉ)|>L10|Lv(œÉ)|‚é´‚é¨‚é≠.

Finally, for each v‚ààV and e‚ààE we define a flaw expressing that v is uncolored (because of e), namely

fev={œÉ‚ààŒ©:œÉ(v)=e}.

Let Fv=Bv‚à™Zv‚à™e‚ààEfev and let Œ©+=Œ©‚àí‚à™v‚ààVFv.

Lemma 6.1 (The Second Phase [38]).

Given œÉ‚ààŒ©+, a complete list-coloring of G can be found efficiently.

The proof of Lemma 6.1 is an a fairly standard application of the (algorithmic) LLL, showing that œÉ can be extended to a complete list-coloring by coloring all Blank vertices with actual colors. Thus, the heart of the matter is reaching a state i.e., (a partial coloring) not suffering from any of the flaws specified above.

Flaw Choice

The algorithm can use any œÄ-strategy in which every B-flaw has priority over every Z- and f-flaw.

The Actions

To address fev at œÉ, i.e., to color v, the algorithm simply chooses a color from Lv(œÉ) uniformly and assigns it to v. The fact that B-flaws have higher priority than f-flaws implies that there are always at least L choices.

Addressing B- and Z- flaws is significantly more sophisticated. For each vertex v, for each vertex u‚ààNv, let Rvu(œÉ)‚äáLu(œÉ) comprise those colors having the property that assigning them to u in state œÉ creates no monochromatic edge except, perhaps, in Ev. To address either Bv or Zv in œÉ, the algorithm performs the following, i.e., the set of actions and the distribution on them as induced by the following procedure.

To see why we give B-flaws priority over Z-flaws, consider œÉ‚ààZv such that Rvu(œÉ)={Blank} for every u‚ààNv. Since Recolor(v,œÉ)=œÉ, addressing Zv would amount to getting stuck. But since œÉ‚ààBu for every u‚ààNv, addressing these B-flaws first creates ‚Äúroom‚Äù to address Zv.

Lemma 6.2.

Let S‚Ä≤(v,œÉ) be the set of colorings that can be reached at the end of Step 2 of recolor(v,œÉ) and let S‚Ä≤‚Ä≤(v,œÉ) be the set of possible final colorings. Then |S‚Ä≤(v,œÉ)|=|S‚Ä≤‚Ä≤(v,œÉ)|.

Proof.

Since Steps 4‚Äì6 are deterministic, |S‚Ä≤‚Ä≤(v,œÉ)|‚â§|S‚Ä≤(v,œÉ)|. To prove that |S‚Ä≤‚Ä≤(v,œÉ)|‚â•|S‚Ä≤(v,œÉ)|, we will prove that if u‚ààNv has distinct colors in œÉ‚Ä≤1,œÉ‚Ä≤2‚ààS‚Ä≤, then there exists z‚ààV such that œÉ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤1(z)‚â†œÉ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤2(z). Imagine that in Step 6, we also oriented e to point away from u. Then, in the resulting partial orientation, every vertex would have outdegree at most 1 and there would be no directed cycles. Consider the (potentially empty) oriented paths starting at u in œÉ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤1 and œÉ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤2 and let z be their last common vertex. If z is uncolored, then œÉ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤1(z)=e1 and œÉ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤2(z)=e2, where e1‚â†e2; if z is colored, then œÉ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤i(z)=œÉ‚Ä≤i(u). ‚àé

Proof of Lemma 6.3

Proof of part (a).

Addressing Bv or Zv by executing Recolor(v,‚ãÖ) only changes the color of vertices in Nv, with any resulting uncolorings being due to edges in Ev. Thus, only flaws in Sv may be introduced. Addressing fev, by coloring v, trivially, can only introduce flaws Bu,Zu, where u‚ààNv. ‚àé

Proof of part (b).

Since addressing an f-flaw never introduces another f-flaw, we only need to discuss procedure Recolor. Therein, vertices are uncolored serially in time, so that any time a vertex w is uncolored there exists, at the time of w‚Äôs uncoloring, a monochromatic edge e={w,u}. Therefore, an edge e={u1,u2} can never be the reason for the uncoloring of both its endpoints, i.e., feu1‚à©feu2=‚àÖ. ‚àé

Proof of part (c).

If addressing fev results in œÉ‚Ä≤, then the previous state œÉ must be the mutation of œÉ‚Ä≤ that results by assigning e to v. Since œÄ(œÉ)=fev implies œÉ‚àâBv, it follows that |Lv(œÉ)|‚â•L. Since colors are chosen uniformly from Lv(œÉ), it follows that Œ≥(fev)‚â§1/L. ‚àé

Proof of parts (d) and (e).

We start by making the following general observation. Let us say that a flaw is primary if it is never eradicated collaterally. For a given set X‚äÜF of primary flaws and an arbitrary set S‚äÜF, write SX=S‚à©X. An argument akin to the one of Section 4.3 shows that for any f‚ààF and S‚äÜF, when defining Œ≥S(f) we can consider the matrix that results by zeroing-out every entry ASf(œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤) such that the set of primary flaws introduced by œÉ‚ÜíœÉ‚Ä≤ is a strict superset of SX, i.e., SX‚äÇUX(œÉ‚Ä≤)‚àñ(UX(œÉ)‚àñ{f}).

Observe that every flaw corresponding to an uncolored vertex is primary since procedure Recolor never colors an uncolored vertex and addressing fev only colors v. Letting X be the set of primary flaws corresponding to uncolored vertices, we see that when computing Œ≥S(f), for f‚àà{Bv,Zv} and S‚äÜF, we can restrict to pairs (œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤) such that the set of uncolored vertices in œÉ‚Ä≤ is exactly the union of the set of uncolored vertices in œÉ and the set {u‚ààNv:feu‚ààS}. Fixing f‚àà{Bv,Zv}, S‚äÜF, and œÉ‚Ä≤, let us denote by InS(f,œÉ‚Ä≤) the candidate set of originating states and by US(f,œÉ‚Ä≤) their common set of uncolored vertices. Then, for any f‚àà{Bv,Zv} and any S‚äÜF,

Œ≥S(f)=maxœÉ‚Ä≤‚ààŒ©‚àëœÉ‚ààInS(f,œÉ‚Ä≤)œÅf(œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤). (31)

To bound œÅf(œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤) in (31) we recall that Recolor assigns to each uncolored vertex u‚ààNv a random color from Rvu(œÉ) and invoke Lemma 6.2 to derive the first equality in (32). For the second equality we observe that for every u‚ààNv, the set Rvu is determined by the colors of the vertices in V‚àñNv. Since Recolor only changes the color of vertices in Nv, it follows that Rvu(œÉ)=Rvu(œÉ‚Ä≤), yielding

œÅf(œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤)=1‚àèu‚ààNv‚àñUS(f,œÉ‚Ä≤)|Rvu(œÉ)|=1‚àèu‚ààNv‚àñUS(f,œÉ‚Ä≤)|Rvu(œÉ‚Ä≤)|:=1ŒõS(f,œÉ‚Ä≤). (32)

Next we bound |InS(f,œÉ‚Ä≤)|, as follows. First we observe that if œÉ‚ààInS(f,œÉ‚Ä≤), then œÉ(u)‚â†œÉ‚Ä≤(u) implies u‚ààNv‚àñUS(f,œÉ‚Ä≤) and, therefore, œÉ(u)‚ààRvu(œÉ‚Ä≤) since œÉ(u)‚ààLu(œÉ)‚äÜRvu(œÉ)=Rvu(œÉ‚Ä≤). Thus, the set of œÉ‚Ä≤-mutations that result by recoloring each vertex in Nv‚àñUS(f,œÉ‚Ä≤) with a color from Rvu(œÉ‚Ä≤) so that the resulting state belongs in f is a superset of InS(f,œÉ‚Ä≤). Denoting this last set by Viol(f,œÉ‚Ä≤), we conclude that

Œ≥S(f)=maxœÉ‚Ä≤‚ààŒ©|InS(f,œÉ‚Ä≤)|ŒõS(f,œÉ‚Ä≤)‚â§maxœÉ‚Ä≤‚ààŒ©|Viol(f,œÉ‚Ä≤)|ŒõS(f,œÉ‚Ä≤)=maxœÉ‚Ä≤‚ààŒ©Pr[\sc recolor(v,œÉ‚Ä≤)‚ààf], (33)

where for the last equality we use the definition of ŒõS(f,œÉ‚Ä≤).

Remark 6.1.

We note that expressing the sum of the transition probabilities into a state in terms of a random experiment as we do in (33) was the key technical idea of [38] in order to apply the entropy compression method. It is also the one that breaks down if we allow our algorithm to go through improper colorings.

Lemma 6.4.

For each vertex v and œÉ‚ààŒ©:

  1. Pr[\sc recolor(v,œÉ‚Ä≤)‚ààBv]‚â§2e‚àíL6.

  2. Pr[\sc recolor(v,œÉ‚Ä≤)‚ààZv]‚â§3qe‚àíL60.

7 Proof of the Witness Tree Lemma for Commutative Algorithms

In this section we state and prove the witness tree lemma for our setting. To do so, we will first need to recall the definition of witness trees from [41] (slightly reformulated to fit our setting).

For a trajectory Œ£=œÉ1w1‚àí‚Üí‚Ä¶œÉtwt‚àí‚ÜíœÉt+1, where œÉiwi‚àí‚ÜíœÉi+1 denotes that flaw fwi was addressed at the i-th step, we define the witness, W(Œ£), of Œ£ to be (w1,‚Ä¶,wt). A witness tree œÑ=(T,‚ÑìT) is a finite rooted, unordered tree T along with a labelling ‚ÑìT:V(T)‚Üí{1,2,‚Ä¶,m} of its vertices with indices of flaws such that the children of a vertex v‚ààV(T) receive labels from N(‚Ñì(v)). To lighten the notation, we sometimes write [v] to denote ‚Ñì(v) and V(œÑ) instead of V(T). Given a witness W=(w1,w2,‚Ä¶,wt) we associate with each i‚àà{1,2,‚Ä¶,t} a witness tree œÑW(i) that is constructed as follows: Let œÑ(i)W(i) be an isolated vertex labelled by wi. Then, going backwards for each j=i‚àí1,i‚àí2,‚Ä¶,1: if there is a vertex v‚ààœÑj+1W(i) such that [v]‚àºwj then we choose among those vertices the one having the maximum distance (breaking ties arbitrarily) from the root and attach a new child vertex u to v that we label wj to get œÑ(j)W(i). If there is no such vertex v then œÑ(j+1)W(i)=œÑ(j)W(i). Finally, let œÑW(i)=œÑ(1)W(i).

We will say that a witness tree œÑ occurs in a trajectory Œ£ if W(Œ£)=(w1,w2,‚Ä¶,wt) and there is k‚àà{1,2,‚Ä¶,t} such that œÑW(k)=œÑ. For an arbitrary permutation œÄ of {1,2,‚Ä¶,m} let œáœÄ(œÑ) be the ordered witness tree that is induced by ordering the children of each node in œÑ from left to right, increasingly according to œÄ.

Theorem 7.1 (Witness Tree Lemma).

Assume that A is commutative with respect to ‚àº and let œÄ be an arbitrary permutation of {1,2,‚Ä¶,m}. Then, for every witness tree œÑ we have that:

Pr[œÑ]‚â§Œªinit|œÑ|‚àèi=1Œ≥[vi],

where (v1,v2,‚Ä¶,v|œÑ|) are the vertices of œáœÄ(œÑ) in backward breadth first order.

Finally, we prove a structural property of the witness trees that might occur during the execution of the algorithm which will be helpful in our analysis.

Proposition 7.2.

For a witness tree œÑ=(T,‚ÑìT) let Li=Li(œÑ) denote the set of labels of the nodes at distance i from the root. For each i‚â•0, and each Œ±,Œ≤‚ààLi we have that Œ±‚âÅŒ≤.

Proof.

Let W=(w1,w2,‚Ä¶,wt) be a witness sequence that can occur in an execution of our algorithm. Let Œ±,Œ≤ be two distinct elements of Li. By the definition of œÑ, labels Œ±,Œ≤ correspond to two indices wj1,wj2 of W. Assume without loss of generality that j1<j2. Then, according to the algorithm for constructing œÑ, index wj2 is ‚Äúattached first‚Äù to the i-th level of œÑ. The proof is concluded by noticing that if wj1=Œ±‚àºŒ≤=wj2 then the node corresponding to wj2 is eligible to be a child of the node corresponding to wj1 during the construction of œÑ and, thus, Œ≤‚àâLi, which is a contradiction.

We will assume without loss of generality that our algorithm follows a deterministic canonical flaw choice strategy. In words, pi(œÉ) always gives priority to flaw fi, unless fi is not present in œÉ in which case it selects the flaw corresponding to the lowest index in U(œÉ). We also define function Swap that takes as input a canonical flaw choice strategy S1=(s1,‚Ä¶,si‚àí1,si,‚Ä¶), a set of witnesses W1, a witness W=(w1,w2‚Ä¶wt)‚ààW1 and an integer i‚àà{1,2,‚Ä¶,|W|} such that wi‚àí1‚âÅwi, and outputs (S2,W2) defined as follows:

  • S2=(s1,‚Ä¶,pwi,pwi‚àí1,si+1,‚Ä¶);

  • W2 is obtained from W1 by changing every witness W‚Ä≤=(w‚Ä≤1,w‚Ä≤2,‚Ä¶,w‚Ä≤i‚àí1,w‚Ä≤i,‚Ä¶)‚ààW1 such that w‚Ä≤i=wi and w‚Ä≤i‚àí1=wi‚àí1 to W‚Ä≤‚Ä≤=(w‚Ä≤1,w‚Ä≤2,‚Ä¶,w‚Ä≤i,w‚Ä≤i‚àí1,‚Ä¶).

We now describe the algorithm that achieves the transformation of (S,W) to (S‚Ä≤,W‚Ä≤) and then prove its correctness. For a witness sequence W‚ààW(œÑ) and a vertex vi of œÑ, let pW(vi) denote the position of the element that corresponds to [vi] in W. The algorithm is as follows.

  1. Set S‚Ä≤‚ÜêS and W‚Ä≤(œÑ)‚ÜêW(œÑ)

  2. For i=1 to |œÑ|

    • While there exist W‚ààW‚Ä≤(œÑ) for which pW(vi)‚â†i

      • (S‚Ä≤,W‚Ä≤(œÑ))‚ÜêSwap(S‚Ä≤,W‚Ä≤(œÑ),W,pW(vi))

First notice that if the algorithm terminates then each witness W‚ààW‚Ä≤(œÑ) has ([v1],[v2],‚Ä¶,[v|œÑ|]) as a prefix. Moreover, it always terminates because at every step, if W=(w1,‚Ä¶,wt) is the input of Swap, then wpW(i)‚âÅwpW(i)‚àí1. To see this, observe that the fact that there exists t‚àà{1,2,‚Ä¶,|W|} such that œÑW(t)=œÑ implies that fwpW(vi)‚àí1 is either a flaw that appears in œÑ and corresponds to a vertex at the same level with fwpW(vi) or doesn‚Äôt appear in œÑ. Proposition 7.2 and the definition of the algorithm for constructing witness trees guarantee that in both these cases we have wpW(i)‚âÅwpW(i)‚àí1.

Finally, we need to show that (39) is true. To that end, we prove the following invariant regarding Swap, concluding the proof.

Lemma 7.5.

Fix any set of witnesses W and canonical flaw choice strategy S. For some W‚àó‚ààW and k‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,|W‚àó|}, let . Then,

‚à•‚à• ‚à•‚à•‚àëW‚ààW(œÑ)Œ∏‚ä§|W|‚àèi=1Awi,si‚à•‚à• ‚à•‚à•1‚â§‚à•‚à• ‚à•‚à•‚àëW‚Ä≤‚ààW‚Ä≤(œÑ)Œ∏‚ä§|W‚Ä≤|‚àèi=1Aw‚Ä≤i,s‚Ä≤i‚à•‚à• ‚à•‚à•1.

Appendix A Comparison to Previous Algorithmic LLL Criteria

Recall that, by definition, Œ≥‚àÖi‚â•Œ≥Si, for all S‚äÜ[m]. To lighten notation, we write Œ≥‚àÖi=Œ≥i.

a.1 Uniform Random Walks [3]

If we take M=I/|Œ©|, then Œ≥i=‚à•Ai‚à•. In [3], addressing a flaw fi at œÉ‚ààfi always amounts to choosing uniformly among the available actions for doing so. Let Di be the digraph on Œ© corresponding to the non-zero entries of Ai. To bound ‚à•Ai‚à•1 observe that the 1-norm of each column œÉ‚Ä≤ is bounded by Indegi(œÉ‚Ä≤)√ó the largest entry in column œÉ‚Ä≤. Since actions are always chosen uniformly, if that largest entry occurs in row œÉ it must equal 1/Outdegi(œÉ). Therefore, we see that (1) recovers (and sharpens) the condition of [3], since

Œ≥i=‚à•MAiM‚àí1‚à•1‚â§max(œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤)‚ààDiIndegi(œÉ‚Ä≤)Outdegi(œÉ)‚â§maxœÉIndegi(œÉ)minœÉOutdegi(œÉ).

a.2 Resampling Oracles [32]

The resampling oracles formulation of Harvey and Vondr√°k [32] requires that for every flaw fi, the transition probabilities œÅi are such that for every œÉ‚Ä≤‚ààŒ©,

1Œº(fi)‚àëœÉ‚ààfiŒº(œÉ)œÅi(œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤)=Œº(œÉ‚Ä≤). (42)

One can interpret (42) as requiring the following: if œÉ‚ààfi is sampled according to Œº and flaw fi is addressed at œÉ, then the resulting state œÉ‚Ä≤ should be distributed exactly according to Œº, i.e., addressing fi should perfectly remove the conditional of the state having been in fi. For example, if Œº is a product measure, this is precisely what is achieved by the resampling algorithm of Moser and Tardos [41].

Taking M=diag(Œº(œÉ)) we see that (1) recovers the condition of [32], since, by (42),

Œ≥i=‚à•MAiM‚àí1‚à•1=maxœÉ‚Ä≤‚ààŒ©1Œº(œÉ‚Ä≤)‚àëœÉ‚ààfiŒº(œÉ)œÅi(œÉ,œÉ‚Ä≤)=Œº(fi).

a.3 Approximate Oracles [2, 37]

As discussed in the introduction, the charge of each flaw in [2, 37] equals Œ≥i=Œ≥‚àÖi=‚à•MAiM‚àí1‚à•1‚â•Œº(fi), where the last inequality is due to the fact (42) need not hold. Allowing for actions and transition probabilities that distort the measure Œº in the above experiment, so that Œ≥i=diŒº(fi) for some distortion factor di>1, can pay off by making the dependency graph sparser. As shown in [2, 37], when the dependency graph is undirected, one can generalize (1) to the cluster expansion criterion [14] and Shearer‚Äôs criterion [46].

a.4 This Paper: Point to Set Correlations

When M=diag(Œº(œÉ)) and ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à•=‚à•‚ãÖ‚à•1, we see that for an arbitrary set S,

Œ≥Si=‚à•MASiM‚àí1‚à•1=(maxœÉ‚Ä≤‚ààŒ©ŒΩSi(œÉ‚Ä≤)Œº(œÉ))Œº(fi),

where ŒΩSi(œÉ‚Ä≤) is the the probability of reaching state œÉ‚Ä≤ in the aforementioned experiment via a transition that introduced every flaw in S (and perhaps more). Thus, in this case, Theorem 3.1 is a refinement of the notion of distortion by the algorithm of the probability measure Œº.

c.1 Proof of Lemma c.2

We follow an approach similar to the one of Lemma 2.3 in [7] making appropriate modifications as needed. First we partition the vertices of G into Œî1‚àíŒ∏ parts by coloring them randomly and independently with Œî1‚àíŒ∏ colors. For a vertex v and a neighbor u adjacent to it, call u a bad neighbor of v, if u and v have at least Œî1‚àí(1+Œ∂/2)Œ∏ common neighbors. Otherwise, say that u is a good neighbor. Since the neighbors of every vertex span at most Œî2‚àí(2+Œ∂)Œ∏ edges, there are at most 2Œî1‚àí(1+Œ∂/2)Œ∏ bad neighbors for any vertex in G.

For any vertex v, define three types of bad event with respect to the random partitioning experiment.

  • Av: more than (1+Œ∏)ŒîŒ∏ neighbors of v receive the same color as v.

  • Bv: more than 10Œ∏Œ∂ bad neighbors of v receive the same color as v.

  • Cv: the good neighbors of v that receive the same color as v span more than 100(Œ∏Œ∂)2 edges.

We will use the symmetric version of the Local Lemma [20] to show that we can find a coloring of the graph that avoids all bad events. First, note that each of the bad events Av,Bv,Cv is independent of all but at most Œî2 others, as it independent of all events Au,Bu,Cu corresponding to vertices u whose distance from v is more than 2. Since the degree of any vertex in its colors class is binomially distributed with mean at most ŒîŒ∏, standard Chernoff estimates imply that the probability that v has more than (1+Œ∏)ŒîŒ∏ neighbors of the same color as that of v is at most e‚àíŒ©(ŒîŒ∏), which means that Pr[Av]<Œî‚àí3 for large enough Œî. Moreover, we also have

Pr[Bv]‚â§(2Œî1‚àí(1+Œ∂/2)Œ∏10Œ∏Œ∂)(1Œî1‚àíŒ∏)10Œ∏Œ∂‚â§‚éõ‚éù2ŒîŒ∏Œ∂2‚éû‚é†10Œ∏Œ∂‚â§Œî‚àí3,

for large enough Œî. Finally, to bound the probability of Cv we make the following observation. If a graph has at least e2 edges, then either it has a vertex of degree at least e, or every vertex has degree strictly less than e, implying that the graph can be edge-colored with ‚åàe‚åâ colors, in which case the largest color class must contain at least e2/‚åàe‚åâ‚â•e‚àí1 edges. Thus, a graph with more than 100/(Œ∏Œ∂)2 edges either has a vertex of degree at least 10/(Œ∏Œ∂)‚â•9/(Œ∏Œ∂) or a matching with at least 10/(Œ∏Œ∂)‚àí1‚â•9/(Œ∏Œ∂) edges, where the inequality follows from the fact that Œ∏,Œ∂<1. Thus, Cv can happen only if there is a good neighbor u of v such that u and v have at least 9/(Œ∏Œ∂) common neighbors with the same color as v, or if there is a matching of size at least 9/(Œ∏Œ∂) on the good neighbors of v that have the same color as v. The probabilities of the first and second of these events are bounded, respectively, by

Œî(Œî1‚àí(1+Œ∂/2)Œ∏9Œ∏Œ∂)(1Œî1‚àíŒ∏)9Œ∏Œ∂‚â§‚éõ‚éù1ŒîŒ∏Œ∂2‚éû‚é†9Œ∏Œ∂‚â§12Œî‚àí3,
(Œî2‚àí(2+Œ∂)Œ∏9Œ∏Œ∂)((1Œî1‚àíŒ∏)2)9Œ∏Œ∂‚â§(1ŒîŒ∏Œ∂)9Œ∏Œ∂‚â§12Œî‚àí3.

Therefore the probability of Cv is at most Œî‚àí3. Thus, the Local Lemma applies since each bad event has probability at most Œî‚àí3 and is independent of all but at most Œî2 other bad events. This means that we can find a partition V=V1,‚Ä¶,Vk, where k=Œî1‚àíŒ∏, so that in each induced subgraph G[Vi], every vertex: has degree at most (1+Œ∏)ŒîŒ∏, has at most 10Œ∏Œ∂ bad neighbors, and is contained in at most 100(Œ∏Œ∂)2 triangles in which both other vertices are good. We will show that, given such a partition, each G[Vi] can be colored with at most (1+Œ∂)(1+Œ∏‚àí1)ŒîŒ∏lnŒî colors, assuming Œî is large enough.

To see this, consider the partition Bi,Vi‚àñBi of Vi, where Bi is the set of vertices u‚ààVi for which there exists a vertex v‚ààVi, such that u is a bad neighbor of v. We claim that œá(G[Bi])‚â§20Œ∏Œ∂+1 and œá(G[Vi‚àñBi])‚â§(1+Œ∂/2)(1+Œ∏‚àí1)ŒîŒ∏lnŒî. Assuming this claim, observe that

œá(G[Vi])‚â§20Œ∏Œ∂+1+(1+Œ∂/2)(1+Œ∏‚àí1)ŒîŒ∏lnŒî‚â§(1+Œ∂)(1+Œ∏‚àí1)ŒîŒ∏lnŒî,

where the last inequality holds for all Œî‚â•ŒîŒ∏,Œ∂.

To see the first part of the claim, note that it is well-known (and easy to see) that if a graph has an orientation with maximum outdegree d, then it is (2d+1)-colorable. Consider the orientation of the graph on Bi that results when every vertex points to its bad neighbors in Bi. Clearly, the maximum outdegree is at most 10Œ∏Œ∂ and, thus, œá(G[Bi])‚â§20Œ∏Œ∂+1 .

To see the second part of the claim, observe that each vertex of G[Vi‚àñBi] is contained in at most 100(Œ∏Œ∂)2 triangles. Let Œî‚àó=(1+Œ∏)ŒîŒ∏ and

f=((1+Œ∏)ŒîŒ∏)2100/(Œ∏Œ∂)2=(Œ∏Œ∂)2Œî2‚àó100‚â•Œî2+2Œ∂31+2Œ∂3‚àó(lnŒî‚àó)2,

where the last inequality holds for Œî‚â•ŒîŒ∏,Œ∂. Applying Theorem 3.4 to G[Vi‚àñBi] (by plugging in Œ∂/3 for the œµ in Theorem 3.4 ) we get that, for all Œî‚â•ŒîŒ∏,Œ∂,

œá‚Ñì(G[Vi‚àñBi]) ‚â§ (1+Œ∂/3)Œî‚àóln‚àöf
= (1+Œ∂/3)(1+Œ∏)ŒîŒ∏ln(1+Œ∏)Œ∏Œ∂ŒîŒ∏10
= (1+Œ∂/3)(1+Œ∏)ŒîŒ∏Œ∏lnŒî+ln(1+Œ∏)Œ∏Œ∂10
‚â§ (1+Œ∂/2)(1+Œ∏)Œ∏ŒîŒ∏lnŒî
= (1+Œ∂/2)(1+Œ∏‚àí1)ŒîŒ∏lnŒî,

as claimed.

Appendix D Proof of Corollary 3.3

We use the term ‚Äúwith high probability‚Äù to refer to probabilities that tend to 1 as n goes to infinity. Corollary 3.3 follows in a straightforward way from the following lemma.

Lemma D.1.

For any Œ¥‚àà(0,1) there exists a constant d0 such that, for any d‚àà(d0lnn,(nlnn)13), each vertex of the random graph G=G(n,d/n) is contained in at most ŒîŒ¥ triangles with high probability, where Œî is the maximum degree of G.

Proof of Corollary 3.3.

According to [5], for a graph G‚ààG(n,d/n) we know that with high probability

œá(G)=12dlnd(1+o(1)). (50)

Fix Œ∂‚àà(0,1) and Œ¥‚àà(0,2Œ∂1+2Œ∂). According to Lemma D.1, there exists a constant d0 such that for any d‚àà(d0lnn,(nlnn)13) each vertex of G=G(n,d/n) is contained in at most ŒîŒ¥ triangles with probability that tends to 1 as n goes to infinity. Thus, we can apply the sparse case of Theorem 3.2 with parameter Œ∂>0 since

f=Œî2ŒîŒ¥>Œî2‚àí2Œ∂1+2Œ∂(lnŒî)2,

for large enough Œî. This yields an upper bound q on the chromatic number of G that is at most

q = (1+Œ∂)Œîln‚àöf (51)
‚â§ (1+Œ∂)Œî1+Œ∂1+2Œ∂lnŒî+lnlnŒî
‚â§ (1+2Œ∂)ŒîlnŒî.

Moreover, since the expected degree of every vertex of G is d and its distribution is binomial with parameter dn, standard Chernoff bounds and the union bound imply that for any Œ∑‚àà(0,1), Œî‚â§(1+Œ∑)d with high probability, for large enough d0.

Combining the latter fact with (50) and (51), we deduce that we can find an arbitrarily small constant Œ∑‚Ä≤‚àà(0,1) such that

by choosing Œ∂ and Œ∑ sufficiently small. Picking Œ∑‚Ä≤=4œµ1‚àí2œµ we obtain œá(G)‚â•q2+Œ∑‚Ä≤‚â•q(12‚àíœµ), concluding the proof of Corollary 3.3. ‚àé

d.1 Proof of Lemma d.1

Let Œîv be the random variable that equals the degree of vertex v of G. Observe that Œîv‚àºBinom(n‚àí1,dn) and, therefore, using a standard Chernoff bound and the fact that d‚â•d0logn we get that

Pr[Œîv‚àâ(1¬±110)d]‚â§1n2,

for large enough d0. Thus, by a union bound we get that Pr[Œî‚àà(1¬±110)d]‚â§1n.

Let Tv be the number of triangles that contain vertex v and B be the event that Œî‚àâ(1¬±110)d. Then,

Pr[Tv>ŒîŒ¥]‚â§Pr[Tv>ŒîŒ¥‚à£¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬ØB]+Pr[B]‚â§Pr[(Tv>ŒîŒ¥)‚à©¬Ø¬Ø¬Ø¬ØB]1‚àí1n+1n.

Pr[Tv>ŒîŒ¥]‚â§e‚àíŒ≤2d3/2n3‚â§1n2

since

Œ≤ ‚â• ((1‚àí110)d)Œ¥‚àíd3/2nd3/2n>0,
13Œ≤2d32n ‚â• 13(((1‚àí110)d)Œ¥‚àíd3/2n)2d3/2n‚â•2lnn,

whenever d‚àà[d0lnn,(nlnn)13] and for large enough n and d0. Taking a union bound over v concludes the proof of the lemma.
